G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related provisions, the Newton Division of the District Court Department has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action, including personal injury actions where the amount in controversy does not exceed the statutory jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2\u20139.proposition: Venue is proper in the Newton District Court because the cause of action arose within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court, namely at the Parks and Recreation Trails located at or near 45 Park Ave, Newton, Massachusetts.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable injury to others by his conduct.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly articulates the general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, with foreseeability of harm as a precondition. That statement is not limited to the firearm-storage facts of the case; it is framed as a general rule of negligence law and cites prior authority and the Restatement, so the case supports the broad proposition about duty and foreseeable injury.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. See Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990)….”

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable injury to others by his conduct.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence elements and explicitly resolves the case on the ground of lack of causation, expressly declining to decide whether the defendant owed any duty of care to the plaintiffs. It does not articulate a general Massachusetts rule that every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable injury to others; rather, it assumes arguendo that a duty may exist and holds that, regardless, plaintiffs failed on causation. Thus, it is not proper authority for the broad duty proposition stated.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control and custody of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the control, supervision, and restraint of the Dog so as to prevent the Dog from causing foreseeable harm to others lawfully using the Park.
*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory strict liability of a dog’s owner or keeper under G.L. c. 140, § 155, and procedural issues about pleading and proof of ownership/keeping. It does not discuss a common-law negligence duty to exercise reasonable care in controlling or restraining a dog, nor does it address duties specific to persons lawfully using a park or other public place. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the negligence-duty proposition stated.
*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u.relevant_excerpt: “G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: ‘The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.’ … Here if Agostino and Rachele jointly were both owners and keepers of the dog, a liability would be established. … He was right in pointing out that … harboring with an assumption of custody, management and control of the dog was evidence of keeping even if not of ownership.”

*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control and custody of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the control, supervision, and restraint of the Dog so as to prevent the Dog from causing foreseeable harm to others lawfully using the Park.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns a premises-liability negligence claim against a store that was *not* the owner or keeper of the dog. The court explicitly analyzes the defendant’s duty only as a storekeeper to keep premises reasonably safe, and it emphasizes that, at common law, even an owner or keeper of a dog has no duty absent knowledge (or reason to know) of dangerous propensities. The opinion does not state or recognize a general duty of a dog owner or custodian to exercise reasonable care to restrain the dog to prevent foreseeable harm to lawful park users; rather, it finds no negligence on these facts and sustains judgment for the defendant.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff can recover only upon proof of breach of the defendant’s duty to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer. … Reasonable care to keep the premises safe for customers from harm caused by animals is within the scope of this duty. … Apart from statute even an owner or keeper of a dog … is not liable for bodily injuries inflicted by it in the absence of proof that he knew, or at least should have known, its dangerous propensities … and in the absence of proof of some fault of such owner or keeper.”

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 136A\u2013174E.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations governing the control and restraint of dogs in public places, including laws requiring dogs to be restrained by a leash where posted.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations governing the control and restraint of dogs in public places, including laws requiring dogs to be restrained by a leash where posted.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and the treatment of trespassers in premises liability. It does not address duties related to dog control, leashes, or compliance with animal-control statutes or ordinances. Therefore, it cannot be authority for a proposition about a duty to comply with dog restraint laws in public places.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. at 698\u2.proposition: Defendant’s failure to adhere to the posted leash rules and to restrain and control the Dog constitutes unreasonable conduct that falls below the standard of care of a reasonably prudent dog owner under the circumstances.

*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.proposition: Defendant’s failure to adhere to the posted leash rules and to restrain and control the Dog constitutes unreasonable conduct that falls below the standard of care of a reasonably prudent dog owner under the circumstances.
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.support_reasoning: The case concerns premises liability for diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool and the open and obvious danger rule; it does not involve dogs, leash rules, or the standard of care for dog owners. Its holding is that the defendants had no duty to warn because the risk of diving into shallow water was open and obvious, which is unrelated to whether failing to follow leash rules is unreasonable conduct by a dog owner. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition claimed about dog owners’ conduct.
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… However, a landowner is ‘not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.’… [I]t is well established… that a landowner’s duty… ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence.”

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: Violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation intended to protect the public from a certain type of harm is evidence of negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 and states that such a violation does not constitute negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute was intended to prevent. That is precisely the Massachusetts rule described in the proposition: violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof. The court then applies that principle to hold that proof of a statutory violation, without proof of common‑law negligence, is insufficient.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.proposition: Violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation intended to protect the public from a certain type of harm is evidence of negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about a commercial landlord’s common-law duty to protect lawful visitors from reasonably foreseeable criminal acts. It does not discuss statutory, ordinance, or regulatory violations or their evidentiary effect in negligence cases. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that violation of such enactments is evidence of negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. … The question in this appeal is whether the evidence warranted a finding that an attack on the plaintiff was reasonably foreseeable.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that allowing a large dog to run off-leash in a public jogging area and to charge at park users would cause them to take evasive action, including swerving or running away, which could in turn lead to a fall and physical injury.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: This concurrence explicitly agrees with the majority that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that such harm (a fall from evasive action caused by a charging off‑leash dog) was reasonably foreseeable. Thus, this case is being cited for a proposition it does not support; it rejects, rather than affirms, that type of foreseeability in its facts.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that allowing a large dog to run off-leash in a public jogging area and to charge at park users would cause them to take evasive action, including swerving or running away, which could in turn lead to a fall and physical injury.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The case concerns foreseeability and proximate cause where a premises owner leaves a dangerous machine (a forklift) unsecured and an intoxicated third party injures a visitor. It does not involve animals, off‑leash dogs, park or jogging areas, or evasive reactions to a charging animal. While it discusses foreseeability of harm to foreseeable users of the premises, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about off‑leash dogs causing evasive action and resulting falls.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships.”

*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for injuries caused when another person reasonably reacts to the danger created by the actor’s negligence.
*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.support_reasoning: The case is about a manufacturer’s duty and liability in negligence to remote vendees despite lack of privity; it deals with foreseeability, dangerous products, intervening and superseding causes, and abolition of the privity bar. It does not discuss liability for harms arising from a third person’s reasonable reaction to a danger created by the defendant (e.g., rescue or evasive-action scenarios). Because the opinion never addresses injuries stemming from another person’s responsive conduct, it does not support the specific reaction-to-danger proposition.
*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Still another is that the causal relation of a manufacturer’s negligence to the injury may be broken by the intervention of a superseding cause … such as some negligence or fault of another, whereby the manufacturer’s negligence ceases to be the proximate cause of the injury. In the present case no evidence of any superseding cause appears. … But even where there is some intervening negligence of another, that may not constitute a superseding cause if it could have been foreseen.”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–96 (1987)
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for injuries caused when another person reasonably reacts to the danger created by the actor’s negligence.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether the employer’s conduct constituted a superseding cause and on foreseeability of intervening third-party conduct, not on liability for injuries caused by another person’s *reaction* to danger. The court discusses that a tortfeasor remains liable for foreseeable intervening conduct, but the facts involve an industrial accident directly caused by the machine’s design, not by a third party reasonably reacting to a peril created by the defendant. Thus, the case supports a broader foreseeability/superseding cause principle, but not the specific proposition about reasonable rescue or reaction to danger.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a tortfeasor is liable ‘for the foreseeable intervening conduct of a third party whether that conduct is negligent or not.’ Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 352 n.10 (1983), quoting Wilborg v. Denzell, 359 Mass. 279, 285 (1971). … The judge correctly left this issue to the jury through appropriate jury instructions.”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: Plaintiff’s fall and resulting fractured wrist were the direct result of her foreseeable evasive action taken to avoid the Dog, which would not have occurred but for Defendant’s negligent conduct.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns causation for injuries from a plaintiff’s evasive action to avoid a dog, but Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp. involves a police officer injured in an unrelated car collision while responding to an accident involving a sedated patient. The SJC holds that the officer’s injury was outside the scope of foreseeable risk created by the hospital’s alleged negligence and expressly finds no proximate cause. The case neither involves evasive action nor supports liability for such derivative injuries; it instead limits causation and scope-of-risk liability in analogous responder scenarios.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “Leavitt’s injury was not ‘caused’ by the hospital because it falls outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from any negligent conduct that would make the hospital’s alleged misconduct tortious… the harm that befell Leavitt — an injury from a collision not involving the patient — arose not from the ‘same general type of danger’ … that the hospital allegedly should have taken reasonable steps to avoid, but from ‘some other danger’… While a third party nonpatient directly injured by a medicated patient… may be within the scope of foreseeable risk, a police officer injured in an accident in which the patient is not involved is outside that scope.”

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: Plaintiff’s fall and resulting fractured wrist were the direct result of her foreseeable evasive action taken to avoid the Dog, which would not have occurred but for Defendant’s negligent conduct.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns proximate cause where a plaintiff is injured while taking foreseeable evasive action to avoid a dog, a classic ‘negligent dog’ or rescue/evasive-action scenario. Kent v. Commonwealth deals with governmental immunity and proximate cause in the context of a parole board’s decision and an intervening federal agency’s actions leading to a police officer being shot eight years later. The opinion contains no discussion of animals, evasive action, or injuries from attempting to avoid immediate danger; instead, it focuses on remoteness, intervening/superseding causes, and shifting duty, so it does not support the specific proposition asserted.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events have broken the chain of factual causation or, if not, have otherwise extinguished the element of proximate cause and become a superseding cause of the harm.” 437 Mass. at 320–21.

*Jesionek*, 376 Mass. at 105\u201306.proposition: Defendant remains liable because his negligence set in motion the events that led to Plaintiff’s injury, and the risk of a jogger tripping or falling while taking evasive action to avoid a charging dog is within the scope of the risk created by his conduct.

*Solimene*, 399 Mass. at 794\u201396.proposition: Defendant remains liable because his negligence set in motion the events that led to Plaintiff’s injury, and the risk of a jogger tripping or falling while taking evasive action to avoid a charging dog is within the scope of the risk created by his conduct.

*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 394 Mass. 7.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained a fractured wrist and other injuries, and has suffered and will continue to suffer pain and suffering, physical impairment, and emotional distress.
*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 394 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about alleged prosecutorial misconduct in cross-examining a witness in a murder trial. It does not discuss negligence, proximate cause, personal injury, or damages such as pain and suffering, physical impairment, or emotional distress. Therefore it provides no authority for the tort causation and damages proposition stated and is being mis-cited for that purpose.
*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 394 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt:
In conclusion, our examination of the entire record pursuant to this court’s duty under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, reveals no reason why we should disturb the jury’s verdict.

Judgment affirmed.

*Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 4.raw_text: *Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 422 Mass. 126, 134–35 (1996)
*Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff injured by another’s negligence is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by that negligence, including economic and noneconomic damages.
*Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 4.case_name: Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.
*Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is a negligence/liquor-liability case focused on duty, breach, causation, and comparative negligence, including the effect of the decedent’s contributory negligence on both estate and wrongful-death claims. It does not discuss the general measure or categories of damages available in negligence actions, nor does it state that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all proximate economic and noneconomic damages. The only damages-related point is that all damages must be reduced by the percentage of the decedent’s negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85, which is different from the proposition cited.
*Tobin v. Norwood Country Club, Inc.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Because we apply the general law of negligence here, it is wholly appropriate that the principle of contributory negligence apply in full force to reduce any liability. Certainly the recovery on behalf of the decedent’s estate is appropriately reduced by the decedent’s own contributory negligence. The question is raised whether the plaintiffs’ wrongful death action is similarly affected. … [G.L. c. 231, § 85] specifically provides that ‘any damages allowed shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose … death recovery is made.’”

*MacCormack v. Boston Edison Co.*, 423 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff injured by another’s negligence is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by that negligence, including economic and noneconomic damages.
*MacCormack v. Boston Edison Co.*, 423 M.support_reasoning: The opinion in MacCormack is an employment discrimination/retaliation case focused on jury trial rights, retroactivity, and what constitutes an adverse employment action. It does not discuss the general scope of tort damages, proximate cause, or the recoverability of economic and noneconomic damages in negligence actions. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the broad negligence-damages proposition stated.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and related provisions;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to the Massachusetts Constitution and applicable statutes and rules, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.
